title: 114_s1865
content: The "Anna Westin Act of 2015" includes sections on short title, table of contents, findings, definitions, training and education, public service announcements, and clarification of existing parity law. The Congress finds that anorexia nervosa poses a high risk of death, with significant health consequences such as osteoporosis and cardiac issues. Approximately 14.5 million people in the US suffer from eating disorders, with a high rate of comorbidity with other illnesses. Anorexia nervosa is characterized by self-starvation and weight loss. Anorexia nervosa is an eating disorder characterized by self-starvation, weight loss, and fear of gaining weight. It is associated with serious health consequences such as heart failure, kidney failure, and osteoporosis. People with anorexia nervosa are at a high risk of suicide. Bulimia nervosa has a lifetime prevalence between 0.9 and 1.5 percent among women and 0.1 and 0.5 percent among men, with serious health consequences including cardiac, gastrointestinal, and dental problems. Binge eating disorder is characterized by frequent episodes of uncontrolled overeating. Binge eating disorder is common, affecting 3.5% of women and 2.0% of men in the US. It is associated with obesity, high blood pressure, elevated cholesterol levels, and increased risk of various cancers, diabetes, and joint damage. Eating disorders are more common in women, with 4-20% of young women practicing unhealthy dieting, purging, and binge eating. Between 4-20% of young women practice unhealthy dieting, purging, and binge eating, known as OSFED. Eating disorders are also found in men, with similar rates of binge eating disorder in both genders. The use of very thin models in advertising has been linked to consumer attitudes and behaviors. Eating disorders affect all age groups, races, ethnicities, and socioeconomic backgrounds in the US, leading to psychological issues like depression, substance abuse, and suicide. Hospitalizations for eating disorders in children under 12 increased by 119% between 1999 and 2006. SEC. 4. DEFINITIONS. This Act defines "eating disorder" to include various disorders like anorexia nervosa, bulimia nervosa, and binge eating disorder. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Health and Human Services. SEC. 5. TRAINING AND EDUCATION. The Secretary, in consultation with the Secretary of Education, will update and reinstate the BodyWise Handbook with information on eating disorders for males and females. This information will be incorporated into the BodyWorks obesity prevention program curriculum and training modules. Public access to this information will be promoted through various methods. The Office on Women's Health will update the BodyWise Handbook and BodyWorks obesity prevention program with information on eating disorders for males and females. This information will be made publicly available for educating universities and nonprofit entities. SEC. 6. EDUCATION AND TRAINING FOR HEALTH PROFESSIONALS. The Secretary will award grants to eligible entities to integrate training on eating disorders into existing curricula for healthcare professionals. This includes early intervention, levels of treatment, referral procedures, prevention strategies, and treatment methods. Entities must submit an application with a plan for fund usage and training evaluation. Entities receiving grants must develop a training program on eating disorders, including prevention, early intervention, and treatment methods. Training may include educational courses, conferences, and teleconferences on identifying and treating individuals with eating disorders. The training program funded by grants focuses on treating eating disorders, identifying individuals at risk, assessing health risk factors, and creating treatment plans. The effectiveness of the training in increasing knowledge and changing behaviors will be evaluated and reported to the Secretary. SEC. 7. EDUCATION AND TRAINING FOR SCHOOL AND HIGHER EDUCATION PROFESSIONALS. The Secretary will award grants to eligible entities for educational seminars on early identification, intervention, and prevention of behaviors associated with eating disorders, as well as providing resources to those affected. Eligible entities must agree to conduct seminars using educational materials from the BodyWise initiative and relevant research on eating disorders. Eligible entities include states, territories, tribes, and organizations. Eligible entities for grants include states, territories, tribes, and organizations, as well as educational institutions. The Director of the National Institute of Mental Health will conduct public service announcements to educate the public on eating disorders, including types, seriousness, prevention, and effects of media on self-esteem. Collaboration with centers of excellence and community-based resources is required. SEC. 9. CLARIFYING APPLICATION OF EXISTING PARITY LAW. Section 2726 of the Public Health Service Act and Section 712 of the Employee Retirement Income Security Act are amended to address mental health and substance use disorder benefits, including the treatment of permanent exclusions and residential treatment. The Employee Retirement Income Security Act and the Internal Revenue Code are amended to address mental health and substance use disorder benefits, including the prohibition of permanent exclusions and the inclusion of residential treatment. The Employee Retirement Income Security Act and the Internal Revenue Code are amended to include residential treatment in mental health and substance use disorder benefits, prohibiting permanent exclusions for specific conditions or disorders. The Employee Retirement Income Security Act and the Internal Revenue Code are amended to include residential treatment in mental health and substance use disorder benefits, without expanding the scope of services under existing laws. No additional funds are authorized for this Act or its amendments; existing funds will be used instead.
